result.markdown:
--- title: "Statistical Concepts" --- * For each variable, compute the following values. You can use the built-in functions or use the mathematical formulas. + expected value + variance + standard deviation ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_7a419ad5d04e8e26e1c6646ab1f529b9'} ```{.r .cell-code} random_vars <- readRDS("../data/random_vars.rds") random_vars %>% summarise(expectedAge = mean(age), varianceAge = var(age), stdAge = sd(age)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_7c3e76bfc685f483c094a11dff31d0a3'} ```{.r .cell-code} random_vars %>% summarise(expectedIncome = mean(income), varianceIncome = var(income), stdIncome = sd(income)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: * Explain, if it makes sense to compare the standard deviations. No!, because standard deviation only represents how far the samples are from the sample-mean. Whereas, covariance is the measure of linear dependency, but it can not be compared easily. Correlation can have value form -1 to 1 and can be used instead to interpret the relationship between two quantities. * Then, examine the relationship between both variables and compute: + covariance + correlation ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_a80f65d8695a1ef90679e93c94c6aff2'} ```{.r .cell-code} random_vars %>% summarise(covariance = cov(age,income), correlation = cor(age,income)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: * What measure is easier to interpret? Please discuss your interpretation. As stated above, covariance is not easy interpret, therefore, correlation is easier to interpret. * Compute the conditional expected value for: + E[income | age <= 18] + E[income | age $\epsilon$ [18,65)] + E[income | age >= 65] ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_d20663cb57b8c844b6f6184381274f0f'} ```{.r .cell-code} # E[income | age <= 18] mean(random_vars %>% filter(age<=18) %>% select(income) %>% pull(income)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] 389.6074 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_17af3c4a868057efe5c4e9931ee6a870'} ```{.r .cell-code} # E[income | age Ïµ [18,65)] mean(random_vars %>% filter(age>=18 & age<65) %>% select(income) %>% pull(income)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] 4685.734 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_45c2686c7f10255272e944b35ad16884'} ```{.r .cell-code} # E[income | age >= 65] mean(random_vars %>% filter(age>=65) %>% select(income) %>% pull(income)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] 1777.237 ``` ::: :::
